awd_titl_txt: EAGER: Collaborative Research: Developing and Testing an Incubator for Digital Entrepreneurship in Remote Communities
awd_abstract_narration:
Abstract: Public 

This collaborative award supports research to design and evaluate a model for entrepreneurial small-business accelerator optimized for job creation in remote Alaskan communities, in collaboration with indigenous populations. Specific objectives and outcomes of this project include:
*	To conduct two workshops with large-scale community involvement in Noorvik, Alaska and Arviat, Nunavut gathering and linking data to the Exchange for Local Observations and Knowledge of the Arctic (ELOKA) project related to comparative US/Canadian venture capital investment potential in the North American Arctic.
*	To develop a digital incubator/accelerator model specifically optimized towards preparing North American indigenous Arctic entrepreneurs to start businesses in the creative and cultural sectors.
Diversifying and strengthening Alaska's economy aligns strongly with U.S. Arctic Policy for national security and economic development. Alaska is a frontier market with extensive untapped creative entrepreneurial assets. Drawing from existing rural and Pan-Arctic business innovation and research, coupled with direct work with Alaskan communities, the IdEA initiative works to grow the Alaskan economy for the transformative benefit of the United States Arctic and potentially other rural communities in the United States. In addition, this research project will also provide key insights into the infusion of training in entrepreneurship into diverse undergraduate and graduate experiences, as the NSF Strategic Plan 2018-2022 notes such training "can speed the translation of new discoveries into commercial applications" and greatly benefit the nation. 

Abstract: Technical  

The (IdEA) Incubator for Digital Entrepreneurship in the Arctic works with remote Alaskan communities to co-produce transformative digitally-focused and economically-centered knowledge developing a digital incubator/accelerator connecting Alaskan rural entrepreneurs with venture capital. The proposed research activities permit comparative cross-pollination of concepts related to Pan-Arctic labor market opportunities for economic development potential, technological capacity, and cultural capital. The incubator leverages multidisciplinary mixed-methodological community-centered approaches to develop and test coproduction of a framework for scientific and economic knowledge in the field of Community Informatics. IdEA applies optimized entrepreneurial training linking entrepreneurship best practices with venture capital support, enabling rural Alaskan communities to develop and apply their unique expertise for the specific purpose of growing and diversifying their economy in alignment with U.S. Arctic Policy for national security and economic development.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

inst.org_lgl_bus_name: REGENTS OF THE UNIVERSITY OF MINNESOTA

por.por_cntn:
EAGER: Collaborative Research: Developing and Testing an Incubator for Digital Entrepreneurship in Remote Communities

This project was conducted by Dr. Olaf Kuhlke from July 2018 to late November 2021 in collaboration with Dr. Timothy Pasch (University of North Dakota), the headquarters of the Tanana Chiefs Conference (Fairbanks, AK), the Hamlet of Arviat (Nunavut, Canada) and various community participants from the latter two constituencies.

The goal of this project was to develop and test an incubator for digital entrepreneurship in remote communities.

Fieldwork in the pre-COVID-19 summer of 2019 allowed for travel to Fairbanks, Hughes and Huslia, Alaska, as well as Arviat, Nunavut. The initial goal of this field season was to gauge entrepreneurship readiness in the selected communities, to conduct community needs and technology readiness surveys, and to perform a series of listening sessions, identifying entrepreneurship interests, barriers and preparation.

The COVID-19 pandemic prevented fieldwork in the summer of 2020, yet this was replaced with virtual collaboration meetings across the selected communities, and further engagement with additional communities, namely Kinngait, Clyde River, Pond Inlet and Iqaluit, Nunavut (Canada). The summer of 2020 was used to analyze the results of the community survey conducted in 2019, to use these insights to develop and test the incubator curriculum and set to it up in a learning management platform (Canvas LMS). Furthermore, the curriculum was tested with a small pilot group of community member from October 2020 to April 2021, and the results of this work, namely the digital artwork completed by participants we displayed in two exhibits in Bern, Switzerland and Glasgow, Scotland, with the latter being part of the cultural programming for COP 26 in November 2021.

 A second version of the curriculum for the incubator was delivered to the Tanana Chiefs Conference in November 2021, with Dr. Kuhlke and Dr. Pasch conducting a week-long in person workshop for aspiring entrepreneurs in Fairbanks, Alaska. The community survey metadata, publications resulting from this grant, and the finished curriculum has all been shared with the NSF Arctic Data Center, and is publicly available and re-usable.

Outcomes of the project include peer-reviewed publications, two curated digital art exhibits, three complete courses on digital entrepreneurship developed in Canvas LMS (a one-week introductory workshop, a complete twelve-week curriculum on digital entrepreneurship and a six-week course on photography and filmmaking for the visualization of community), and a community needs assessment/technology readiness survey with over 300 respondents across the Arctic.

 

 

 


Last Modified: 04/18/2022
Modified by: Olaf Kuhlke
